abstracts.cdata!:
The Health and Population Project in
            Lesotho was successful. The Bank's interactions were
            highly valued. The Ministry of Health (MOH)'s
            performance during the early stages of the project was
            clearly affected by the lack of an experienced person as
            deputy project coordinator, the person who had
            responsibility for day today monitoring of activities.
            Despite external training early in the project and efforts
            by each supervision mission to assist the Project
            Coordinating Unit (PCU) in utilizing project monitoring
            systems for tracking activities as well as expenditures,
            there was little practical follow-up. More serious, however,
            is the fact that several project objectives were not met
            either because anticipated activities never took place, or
            the Government failed to follow-up as required. The major
            lesson learned is that the project would have benefited a
            lot from a strong start up foundation which would have
            entailed a project launching, strong PCU with management
            systems in place and frequent and consistent missions,
            especially in the first two years of the project. Finally a
            well established project documentation system to assist
            during staff changeovers for both the Bank and the Borrowers.
